III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule Orientation and training
400.12209(1)(a)
(1). An agency shall ensure and document all of the following:
(a) That each social services worker and each social service supervisor
receives not less than 16 hours of orientation after initial appointment and
before assumption of assigned duties.
11 of 12 employee personnel files reviewed did not include an orientation for their
newly hired employees.
CPA Rule Development of service plans
400.12418(2)(b)
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child and
parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least once every
90 calendar days thereafter.
2 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed had updated services plans that were
not completed timely. (20 updated service plans were reviewed.)
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
INTERIM 4/20/23, CAP APPROVED 4/28/23.

CPA Rule Independent living agreement
400.12510(2)
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the youth and the social
service worker. The agreement must be reviewed with the youth at least
once every 90 calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
3 of 3 independent living case files were reviewed. There was no documentation
that the independent living agreement was reviewed and signed by the youth
every 90 days.
FOM POLICY 722 – Family Team Meeting: Types and Timeframes
06B
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as outlined…Updated
Case Plan (USP) – within 30 days prior to the service plan due date.
2 of 9 youth case files (6 foster care, 3 independent living) reviewed, 2 were
missing a required FTM.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
I NTERIM 4/20/23, CAP APPROVED 4/28/23.
FOM POLICY 722-08D T R EATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
S IGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain signatures
from the following individuals, as applicable:
Caseworker, Supervisor, second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
place apart, Parents who are a member of a participating household. Youth
ages 14 and older. Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers. Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the treatment plan: I have
participated in the Development of the Case service plan and the Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
5 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed, and 3 of 3 independent living youth
case files reviewed (19 of 31 PATPs) were either missing required PATP
signatures, signatures not obtained within 30 days of the updated service plans
and yes or no was not checked indicating participation of the updated service
plan.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
INTERIM 4/20/23, CAP APPROVED 4/28/23.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
Special Investigation #2023C0000214 was completed on 3/13/2023. The CAP
was received on 3/28/2023. The agency was in violation with R 400.12206 (1)
Staff qualifications, volunteer, contractors on central registry and R400. 12202
Policy and Procedures.
Interim Inspection dated 4/20/23, CAP approved 5/3/23. It should be noted that
this inspection was completed in December of 2022 but due to system change
over, it was not completed in the system until April of 2023. The agency was in
violation with R400.12312 (3)(h) Foster parent training, R400.12418 (2)(b)
Development of service plans, FOM Policies 722.06B Family Team Meeting,
722.08D Treatment Plan, Required Participation and 801.03 Medical Passport.
The agency continues to work with the violations that were cited in the last
inspection (interim) as they have several repeat violations for this renewal
inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed on 10/17/23. She reported it has
been a struggle with hiring qualified staff but, currently they have filled all vacant
positions. She reported the leadership team is working with the supervisors to
encourage and support the staff and teach the staff how to connect with one
another and create an environment that is supportive and helpful to carry out their
respective duties. The CA reported that managing the work of child welfare has
become increasingly difficult, not because the work is impossible, but because the
manner in which they have managed the work must change. She said the agency

is doing whatever they can to ensure the success of the staff which in turn ensures
the success of the cases that staff are managing. She said whether state or non-
profit, all have struggled post COVID with many of the same things, homes,
staffing, making viable placements, etc. There has been an increased sense of
partnership and connection and she hopes this will remain.
Financial Overview
The agency provided their annual audit by an independent certified public
accountant and an annual budget for the current fiscal year. No concerns were
noted.
Staff Interviews
Staff interviewed were consistent in stating they love the open door policy of
working with their supervisors and managers. They appreciate the flexibility of the
job and getting support from their coworkers and supervisors. Most staff
interviewed were relatively new and said the agency is getting more consistent
with communication among staff and supervisors.
Description of Agency Walk Through
There were no areas of safety concerns noted in the areas of the facility.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were three safety alerts.
Safety Alert 1:
Concern:
On 10/13/23, the caregiver blatantly stated he would not allow an in-person home
visit from DCWL.
Resolution:
Agency case manager and supervisor went to the home on 10/25/2023 and created
a safety plan with the caregivers. The caregivers understand the obligations to allow
workers in the home to verify the wellbeing of the foster child upon request. The
caregivers agreed to the safety plan. Photos of the foster child, her bedroom, smoke
detectors and safety plan are attached to the safety alert for verification of safety.
Safety Alert 2:
Concern:
On 10/27/23, at the home of the caregiver, the basement was not accessible due to
three dogs in the basement and would not move away from the door entrance to the
basement. The youngest foster child (4 Foster children total) in the home sleeps on
a mattress on the floor with no bedframe. There is a relative that visits the home
frequently and sleeps there overnight but has not been assessed by the agency.

Resolution:
On 11/1/2023, the agency caseworker verified that the caregiver has purchased a
toddler bed for the youngest foster child and a toddler bed frame. A safety plan was
signed on 10/31/23 stating that the relative who frequent the home will not spend the
night at the home or be left alone with the foster children. The caregiver stated she
was working on getting the dogs vaccinated and that the dogs will be removed from
the home until they are vaccinated. As of 11/1/23, the dogs were no longer in the
home. Smoke detectors were observed in the basement. The basement is used for
storage and not used as a gathering place. Photos are attached to this safety alert
to show compliance.
Safety Alert 3:
Concern:
On 10/17/23, upon arriving to the home for a scheduled visit to verify safety within
the home and the foster child, no contact was made.
Resolution:
On 10/18/23, the agency case worker visited the caregiver’s home and verified that
the foster home needed some household supplies. The case worker purchased
supplies and took them to the caregiver’s home on 10/23/23 to rectify any safety
concerns. A safety plan was signed. Photos are attached to this safety alert that
includes the foster child’s sleeping environment, all entrances and exits of the home
are unobstructed, the home has working hot and cold water, electricity is on, and the
home is warm. There are no firearm or weapons in the home and no bedroom in the
basement. There are working appliances in the kitchen. The medications are stored
in a lockbox. There are no dangerous chemicals in the home.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that Bethany Christian Services - Southfield will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
